solution.text:
Lets draw a square ABCD, then draw an equilateral triangle (\(\Delta ABP\)) on side AB as shown in figure,
Now, join A to C and draw an equilateral triangle (\(\Delta ACQ\)) on AC
Let, sides of the square be x units
i.e., AB = BC = CD = DA = x
Then,
AC = \(\sqrt 2\)x
Given that:
Area of \(\Delta ABP\) = _{i}_ sq.units,
Since, \(\Delta ABP\) and \(\Delta ACQ\), both are equilateral triangle, thus they are similar triangles as we studied in previous exercises.
Therefore,
By Theorem 6.6, we have,
\(Area(\Delta ABP)\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(AB^2\over AC^2\)
i.e., \(_{i}_\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(x^2\over (\sqrt2x)^2\)
i.e., \(_{i}_\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(x^2\over 2x^2\)
i.e., \(_{i}_\over Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = \(1\over 2\)
i.e., \(Area(\Delta ACQ)\) = _{{2*i}}_

content.text: If the area of an equilateral triangle described on one side of a square is _{i}_ sq.units,then find the area of an equilateral triangle described on one of its diagonal .
